column1: C-reactive protein (CRP) is produced by the liver.
This article discusses the blood test done to measure the amount of CRP in your blood.
You may have this test to: - Check for flare-ups of inflammatory diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, lupus, or vasculitis.
Levels of CRP may not be increased in people with rheumatoid arthritis and lupus.
Generally, there is no CRP detectable in the blood.

According to the American Heart Association, results of the hs-CRP in determining the risk for heart disease can be interpreted as follows: - You are at low risk of developing cardiovascular disease if your hs-CRP level is lower than 1.0 mg/L.
